editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Rule a Wife, AND Have a Wife.
A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the New Theatre, IN Little Lincolns Inn-fields.
LONDON, Printed for Sam. Briſcoe, in Ruſſel-ſtreet, Covent-Garden; and ſold by Richard Wellington, at the Lute in S. Paul's Church-yard. 1697.
☞The Country Wake: A Comedy, written by Mr. Tho. Doggett. Acted at the New-Theatre in Little Lincolns Inn-fields.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Eſtifania, her Maid, Wife to the Copper Captain,

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: PLeaſure attend ye, and about ye ſit
The ſprings of mirth, fancy, delight and wit,
To ſtir you up, do not your looks let fall,
Nor to remembrance our late errors call,
Becauſe this day w'are Spaniards all again,
The ſtory of our Play: and our Seene Spain:
The errors too, do not for this cauſe hate,
Now we preſent their wit and not their ſtate.
Nor Ladies be not angry if you ſee,
A young freſh Beauty, wanton and too fres,
Seek to abuſe her Husband, ſtill 'tis Spain,
No ſuch groſs errors in your Kingdom reign,
W'are Veſtals all, and though we blow the fire,
We ſeldom make it flame up to deſire,
Take no example neither to begin,
For ſome by precedent delight to ſin:
Nor blame the Poet if he ſlip aſide
Sometimes laſciviouſly if not too wide.
But hold your Fans cloſe, and then ſmile at eaſe,
A cruel Scene did never Lady pleaſe.
Nor Gentlemen, pray be not you diſpleas'd,
Though we preſent ſome men fool'd, ſome diſeas, d,
Some drunk, ſome mad: we mean not you, you 're free,
We tax no farther than our Comedy,
You are our friends, ſit noble then and ſee.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Juan de Caſtro, and Michael Perez.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: A Re your Companies full, Collonel?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: No, not yet, Sir:
Nor will be this month yet, as I reckon;
How riſes your Command?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We pick up ſtill, and as our monies hold out,
We have men come, about that time I think
We ſhall be full too, many young Gallants go.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And unexperienced,
The Wats are dainty dreams to young hot ſpirits,
Time and Experience will allay thoſe Viſions;
We have ſtrange things to fill our numbers,
There's one Don Leon, a ſtrange goodly fellow,
Recommended to me from ſome noble Friends,
For my Alferes; had you but ſeen his Perſon,
And what a Giants promiſe it proteſteth.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I have heard of him, and that he hath ſerv'd before too.

sp.speaker: Juan
sp.l: But no harm done, nor never meant, Don Miohael,
That came to my ears yet; ask him a queſtion,
He bluſhes like a Girl, and anſwers little,
To the point leſs; he wears a Sword, a good one,
And good Cloaths too, he is whole skinn'd, has no hurt yet,
Good promiſing hopes; I never yet heard certainly
Of any Gentleman that ſaw him angry.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Preſerve him, he'll conclude a Peace, if need be;
Many as ſtrong as he will go along with us,
That ſwear as valiantly as heart can wiſh,
Their mouths charg'd with ſix oaths at once, and whole ones,
That make the drunken Dutch creep into Mole-hills.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: 'Tis true, ſuch we muſt look for: but Mich. Perez,
When heard you of Donna Margarita, the great Heireſs?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I hear every hour of her, though I never ſaw her,
She is the main diſcourſe: noble Don Juan de Caſtro,
How happy were that man could catch this Wench up,
And live at eaſe! ſhe is fair, and young, ad wealthy.
Infinite wealthy, and as gracious too
In all her entertainments, as men report.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: But ſhe is proud, Sir, that I know for certain
And that comes ſeldom without wantonneſs:
He that ſhall marry her, muſt have a rare hand.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Would I were married, I would find that Wiſdom,
With a light rein to rule my Wife: if ever Woman
Of the moſt ſubtile • ould went beyond me,
I would give the Boys leave to whoot me out o'th' Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, there be two Gentlewomen attend to ſpeak With you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wait on 'em in.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Are they two handſome Women?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They ſeem ſo, very handſom, but they are vail'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Thou put'ſt ſugar in my mouth, how it melts with me!
I love a ſweet young Wench.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wait on them in I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Don Juan.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: How you itch, Michael! how you burniſh!
Will not this Souldiers heat out of your bones yet,
Do your Eyes glow now?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: There be two.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Say honeſt, what ſhame have you then?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I would fain ſee that,
I have been in the Indies twice, and have ſeen ſtrange things,
But two honeſt Women?—one I read of once.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Prithee be modeſt.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I'll be any thing.

div.stage: Enter Servant, Donna Clara, and Eſtiſania vail'd.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You are welcome Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Both hooded, I like 'em well though,
They come not for advice in Law ſure hither;
May be they would learn to raiſe the Pike,
I am for 'em: they are very modeſt, 'tis a fine Preludium.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: With me, or with this Gentleman,
Would you ſpeak Lady?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: With you, Sir, as I gueſs, Juan de Caſtro.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Her Curtain opens, ſhe is a pretty Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am the Man, and ſhall be bound to Fortune,
I may do any ſervice to your Beauties.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Captain, I hear you are marching down to Flanders,
To ſerve the Catholick King.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I have a Kinſman, and a noble Friend,
Imploy'd in thoſe Wars, may be, Sir, you know him,
Don Campuſano Captain of Carbines
To whom I would requeſt your Nobleneſs,
To give this poor Remembrance.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I ſhall do it,
I know the Gentleman, a moſt worthy Captain.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Something in private.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Step aſide? I'll ſerve thee.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Prithee let me ſee thy face.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt pardon me,
Women of our ſort, that maintain fair memories,
And keep ſuſpect off from their Chaſtities,
Had need wear thicker Vails.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I am no blaſter of a Ladies Beauty,
Nor bold intruder on her ſpecial favours,
I know how tender Reputation is,
And with what guards it ought to be preſerv'd, Lady,
You may to me.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You muſt excuſe me, Seignior, I come
Not here to ſell my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman by the honour of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I believe you,
I pray you be civil, I believe you would ſee me,
And when you have ſeen me I believe you will like me,
But in a ſtrange place, to a ſtranger too,
As if I came on purpoſe to betray you:
Indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I ſhall love you dearly,
And 'tis a ſin to fling away affection,
I have no Miſtreſs, no deſire to honour
Any but you, will not this Oyſter open?
I know not, you have ſtruck me with your modeſty;
She will draw ſure; ſo deep, and taken from me
All the deſire I might beſtow on others:
Quickly before they come.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Indeed I dare not:
But ſince I ſee you are ſo deſirous Sir,
To view a poor face that can merit nothing
But your Repentance.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It muſt needs be excellent.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: And with what honeſty you ask it of me,
When I am gone let your man follow me,
And view what houſe I enter, thither come,
For there I dare be bold to appear open:
And as I like your vertuous carriage then,
I ſhall be able to give welcome to you;
She has done her buſineſs, I muſt take my leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I'll kiſs your fair white hand and thank you, Lady.
My man ſhall wait, and I ſhall be your Servant;
Sirrah, come near, hark.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I ſhall do it faithfully.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You will command me no more ſervices;

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: To be careful of your noble health, dear Sir,
That I may ever honour you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I thank you,
And kiſs your hands, wait on the Ladies down there.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: You had the honour to ſee the face that came to you?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And 'twas a fair one; what was yours, Don Michael?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Mine was 'ith' clipſe, and had a Cloud crawn over it.
But I believe well, and I hope 'tis handſome,
She had a hand would ſtir a holy Hetmite.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You know none of 'em?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Then I do, Captain,
Bu 〈◊〉 ſay nothing till I ſee the proof on't,
Sit cloſe Don Perez, or your Worſhip's caught.
I fear a Flye.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Were thoſe ſhe brought Love-Letters?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: A Packet to a Kinſman now in Flanders:
Yours was very modeſt metrought.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Some young unmanag'd thing,
But I may live to ſee—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: 'Tis worth experience,
Let's walk abroad and view our Companies.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: What, are you for the Wars, Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: It may be I,
It may be no, e'n as the humor takes me.
If I find peace amongſt the female Creatures,
And eaſie entertainment, I'll ſtay at home
I am not ſo far obliged yet to long Marches
And mouldy Bisket, to run mad for Honour,
When you are all gone I have my choice before me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Of which Hoſpital thou wilt ſweat in; wilt thou
Never leave whoring?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: There is leſs danger in't than gunning, Sanchio,
Though we be ſhot ſometimes, the ſhot's not mortal,
Beſides, it breaks no limbs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: But it diſables 'em,
Doſt thou ſee how thou pull'ſt thy legs after thee, as they
Hung by points.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Better to poll'em thus than walk on wooden ones:
Serve bravely for a Billet to ſupport me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Fye fye 'tis baſe.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Doſt thou count it baſe to ſuffer?
Suffer abundantly? 'tis the Crown of Honour;
You think it nothing to lie twenty days
Under a Surgeons hands that has no mercy.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: As thou haſt done I am ſure; but I perceive now
Why you deſire to ſtay, the orient Heireſs,
The Margarita, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: I would I had her.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: They ſay ſhe will marry.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: I think ſhe will.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And marry ſuddenly, as report goes too,
She fears her Youth will not hold out, Alonz.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: I would I had the ſheathing on't.

sp.speaker: Sanc
sp.l: They ſay too
She has a greedy eye that muſt be fed
With more than one mans meat.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: Would ſhe were mine,
I would cater for her well enough; but Sanchio,
There be too many great men that adore her,
Princes, and Princes fellows, that claim priviledge.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yet thoſe ſtand offi'th' way of marriage,
To be tyed to a mans pleaſure is a ſecond labour.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: She has bought a brave houſe here in Town.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have heard ſo.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: If ſhe convert it now to pious uſes,
And bid poor Gentlemen welcome.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: When comes ſhe to it?

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: Within theſe two days, ſhe is in the Country yet,
And keeps the nobleſt Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Then there's ſome hope of her,
Wilt thou go my way.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: No, no, I muſt leave you,
And repair to an old Gentlewoman
That has credit with her, that can ſpeak a good word.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Send thee good fortune, but make thy Body ſound firſt.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: I am a Soldier,
And too ſound a Body becomes me not;
Farewel, Sanchio.

div.stage: Enter a servant of Michael Perez.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis this or that houſe, or I have loſt my aim,
They are both fair buildings, ſhe walked plaguy faſt,
And hereabouts I loſt her; ſtay, that's ſhe,
'Tis very ſhe,—ſhe makes me a low court'ſie,
Let me note the place, the ſtreet I will remember.
She is in again, certain ſome noble Lady.
How happy ſhould I be if ſhe love my maſter:
A wonderous goodly houſe, here are brave lodgings,
And I ſhall ſleep now like an Emperor
And ear abundantly: I thank my fortune,
I'll back with ſpeed, and bring him happy tidings.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: What ſhould it mean, that in ſuch haſte
We are ſent for?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: Belike the Lady Margaret has ſome buſineſs
She would break to us in private.

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.l: It ſhould ſeem ſo.
'Tis a good Lady, and a wiſe young Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: And vertuous enough too I warrant ye
For a young Woman of her years; 'tis a pity
To load her tender Age with too much Vertue.

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis more ſometimes than we can well away with.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Good morrow, Ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: 'Morrow my good Madam.

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: How does the ſweet young Beauty, Lady Margaret?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: Has ſhe ſlept well after her walk laſt night?

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.l: Are her dreams gentle to her mind?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: All's well,
She's very well, ſhe ſent for you thus ſuddenly
To give her counſel in a buſineſs
That much concerns her.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: She does well and wiſely,
To ask the counſel of the ancientſt, Madam,
Our years have run through many things ſhe knows not.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: She would fain marry.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis a proper calling.
And well beſeems her years, who would ſhe yoke with?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: That's left to argue on, I pray come in
And break your faſt, drink a good cup or two,
To ſtrengthen your underſtandings, then ſhe'l tell ye.
2. And good wine breeds good counſel,
We'll yeild to ye.

div.stage: Enter Juan de Caſtro and Leon.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Have you ſeen any ſervice?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Every where.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What office bore ye?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None, I was not worthy:

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What Captains know you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None, they were above me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Were you never hurt?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not that I well remember,
But once I ſtole a Hen, and then they beat me;
Pray ask me no long queſtions, I have an ill memory.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This is an Aſſe, did you never draw your ſword yet?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not to do any harm I thank Heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Nor ne'r ta'en priſoner.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No, I ran away.
For I had ne'r no money to redeem me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Can you endure a Drum.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It makes my head ake.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Are you not valiant when you are drunk?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I think not, but I am loving Sir.

sp.speaker: Juan
sp.l: What a lump is this man.
Was your Father wiſe?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Too wiſe for me I'm ſure,
For he gave all he had to my younger Brother.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: That was no fooliſh part I'le bear you witneſs.
Canſt thou lye with a Woman?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I think I could make ſhift Sir,
But I am baſhful.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: In the night?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know not,
Darkneſs indeed may do ſome good upon me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Why art thou ſent to me to be my Officer,
Ay, and commended too, when thou darſt not fight?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There be more Officers of my opinion,
Or I am cozen'd Sir, men that talk more too.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: How wilt thou ſcape a bullet?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why by chance,
They aim at honourable men, alas I am none Sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This fellow has ſome doubts in's talk that ſtrike me,
He cannot be all fool: welcom Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What have you got there, temperance into your Company?
The ſpirit of peace? we ſhall have wars.
By th'ounce then. O here's another pumpion,
Let him looſe for luck ſake, the cram'd ſon
Of a ſtav'd Uſurer, Cacafogo, both their brains butter'd,
Cannot make two ſpoonfuls.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: My Father's dead: I am a man of war too,
Monies, demeſns; I have Ships at Sea too,
Captains.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Take heed o'th' Hollanders, your ſhips may leak elſe.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I ſcorn the Hollanders, they are my Drunkards.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Put up your gold Sir, I'le borrow it elſe.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied, you ſhall not,
Come out, I know thee, meet mine anger inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I never wrong'd ye.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thouhaſt wrong'd mine honour,
Thou lok'dſt upon my Miſtris thrice laſciviouſly,
I'll make it good.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Do not heat your ſelf, you will ſurſeit.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thou wan'ſt my mony too, with a pair of baſe bones,
In whom there was no truth, for which I beat thee,
I beat thee much, now I will hurt thee dangerouſly.
This ſhall provoke thee.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You ſtruck too low by a foot Sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You muſt get a ladder when you would beat
This fellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I cannot chuſe but kick again, pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Hadſt thou not ask'd my pardon, I had kill'd thee,
I leave thee as a thing deſpis'd, aſſoles manus a voſtra ſiniare a Maiſtre.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You have ſcap'd by miracle, there is not in all Spain,
A ſpirit of more fury than this Fire-drake.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I ſee he is haſty, and I would give him leave
To beat me ſoundly if he would take my bond.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What ſhall I do with this fellow?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Turn him off,
He will infect the Camp with cowardiſe,
If he go with thee.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: About ſome week hence Sir.
If I can hit upon no abler, Officer,
You ſhall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I deſire no better.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You have made me now too bountiful amends, Lady,
For your ſtrict carriage when you ſaw me firſt:
Theſe beauties were not menat to be conceal'd,
It was a wrong to hide ſo ſweet an object,
I cou • d now chide ye, but it ſhall be thus,
No other anger ever touch your ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Eſtif
sp.l: You appear to me ſo honeſt, and ſo civil,
Without a bluſh Sir, I dare bid ye welcom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now let me ask your name.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: 'Tis Eſtifania, the heir of this poor place.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Poor do you call it?
There's nothing that I caſt mine eyes upon,
But ſhews both rich and admirable, all the rooms
Are hung as if a Princeſs were to dwell here,
The Gardens, Orchards, every thing ſo curious:
Is all that plate your own too?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: 'Tis but little,
Only for preſent uſe, I have more and richer,
When need ſhall call, or friends compel me uſe it,
The ſutes you ſee of all the upper chambers,
Are thoſe that commonly adorn the houſe,
I think I have beſides, as fair, as civil,
As any Town in Spain can parallel.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now if ſhe be not married, I have ſome hopes.
Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You make me bluſh to anſwer,
I ever was accounted ſo to this hour,
And that's the reaſon that I live retir'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then would I counſel you to marry preſently,
(If I can get her, I am made for ever)
For every year you loſe, you loſe a beauty,
A Husband now, an honeſt careful Husband,
Were ſuch a comfort: will ye walk above ſtairs?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: This place will fit our talk, 'tis fitter far Sir,
Above there are day-beds, and ſuch temptations
I dare not truſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She is excellent wiſe withal too.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You nam'd a husband, I am not ſo ſtrict Sir,
Nor ty'd unto a Virgins ſolitarineſs,
But if an honeſt, and a noble one,
Rich, and a Souldier, for ſo I have vowed he ſhall be,
Were offer'd me, I think I ſhould accept him,
But above all he muſt love.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: He were baſe elſe,
There's comfort miniſtred in the word Souldier,
How ſweetly ſhould I live!

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I am not ſo ignorant, but that I know well,
How to be commanded,
And how again to make my ſelf obey'd Sir,
I waſte but little, I have gather'd much,
My Rial not the leſs worth, when 'tis ſpent,
If ſpent by my direction, to pleaſe my Husband,
I hold it as indifferent in my duty,
To be his maid i'th' Kitchin, or his Cook,
As in the Hall to know my ſelf the Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sweet, rich and provident, now fortune ſtick
To me; I am a Soldier, and a Bachelour, Lady,
And ſuch a Wife as you, I cou'd love infinitely,
They that uſe many words, ſome are deceitful,
I long to be a Husband, and a good one,
For 'tis moſt certain I ſhall make a preſident
For all that follow me to love their Ladies.
I am young you ſee, able I would have you think too,
If't pleaſe you know, try me before you take me.
Tis true I ſhall not meet in equal wealth
With ye, but Jewels, Chains, ſuch as the war
〈◊〉 as given me, a thouſand Duckets I dare
•• ſume on in ready gold, now as your
•• re may handle it, as rich cloaths too, as
〈◊〉 he bears Arms, Lady.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You are a true gentlemen, and fair, I ſee by ye,
• nd ſuch a man I had rather take.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Pray do ſo, I'le have a Prieſt o'th' ſudden.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: And as ſuddenly you will repent too.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'le be hang'd or drown'd firſt,
〈◊〉 this and this, and this kiſs.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You are a Flatteter,
But I muſt ſay there was ſomething when I ſaw you
Firſt, in that moſt noble face, that ſtirr'd my fancy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'le ſtir it better e're you ſleep ſweet Lady,
I'le ſend for all my Trunks, and give up all to ye,
Into your own diſpoſe, before I bed ye,
And then ſweet wench.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You have the art to cozen me.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Margarita, and two Ladies, and Altea.

sp.speaker: Margar.
sp.l: SIT down and give me your opinions ſeriouſly.
〈◊〉 You ſay you have a mind to marry Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 〈…〉 , I have for to preſerve my credit,
〈◊〉 not ſo much for that as for my ſtate Ladies,
〈◊〉 me 〈◊〉 there lies the main o'th' queſtion,
〈…〉 mo • ey will in • p •• it,
〈…〉 gone, when the law ſhall
〈…〉 ſtrip me 〈…〉
〈…〉 body ſo malicious that way?
〈…〉 are that are young and luſty,
〈…〉 my pleaſure,

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis fit you ſhould have,
You years require it, and'tis neceſſary,
As neceſſary as meat to a young Lady,
Sleep cannot nouriſh more.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.l: But might not all this be, and keep ye ſingle.
You take away variety in marriage,
The abundance of the pleaſure you are barr'd then,
Is't not abundance that you aim at?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes why was I made a woman?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: And every day a new?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why fair and young but to uſe it?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: You are ſtill i'th' right, why would you marry then

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Becauſe a Husband ſtops all doubts in this point,
And clears all paſſages.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: What Husband mean ye?

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: A Husband of an eaſy faith, a fool,
Made by her wealth, and moulded to her pleaſure,
One though he ſee himſelf become a monſter,
Shall hold the door, and entertain the maker.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: You grant there may be ſuch a man.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: Yes marry, but how to bring 'em to this rare Perfection.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: They muſt be choſen ſo, things of no honour,
Nor outward honeſty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No 'tis no matter,
I care not what they are, ſo they be luſty.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.l: Methinks now a rich Lawyer, ſome ſuch fellow,
That carries credit, and a face of awe,
But lies with nothing but his clients buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No there's no truſting them, they are too ſubtil,
The Law has moulded'em of natural miſchief.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: Then ſome grave governour,
Some man of honour, yet an eaſy man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: If he have honour I am undone, I'le none ſuch,
I'le have a luſty man, honour will cloy me.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Tis fit ye ſhould Lady;
And to that end, with ſearch and with and labour,
I have found one out, a right one and a perfect,
He is made as ſtrong as braſs, is of brave years too,
And doughty of complexion.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.l: Is he a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Yes and a ſouldier, as gentle as you would wiſh him,
A good fellow, wears good cloaths.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.l: Thoſe I'le allow him,
They are for my credit, does he underſtand
But little?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Very little.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.l: 'Tis the better,
Have not the wars bred him up to anger?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No, he will not quarrel with a dog that bites him,
Let him be drunk or ſober, is one ſilence.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: H'as no capacity what honour is?
For that's the Souldiers god.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Honour's a thing too ſubtil for his wiſdom,
If honour lye in eating, he is right honourable.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is he ſo goodly a man do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: As you ſhall ſee Lady,
But to all this is but a trunk.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I would have him ſo,
I ſhall add branches to him to adorn him,
Go, find me out this man, and let me ſee him,
If he be that motion that you tell me of,
And make no more noiſe, I ſhall entertain him,
Let him be here.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: He ſhall attend your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Why thou art not married indeed?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No, no, pray think ſo,
Alas I am a fellow of no reckoning,
Not worth a Ladies eye

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Wou'dſt thou ſteal a fortune,
And make none of all thy friends acquainted with it,
Nor bid us to thy wedding?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No indeed,
There was no wiſdom in't to bid an Artiſt,
An old ſeducer to a female Banquet,
I can cut up my pye without your inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Was it the wench i'th' veil?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Baſto 'twas ſhe,
The prettieſt Rogue that e're you look'd upon,
The lovingſt thief.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And is ſhe rich withal too?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: A mine, a mine, there is no end of wealth Collonel,
I am an aſſe, a baſhful fool, prethee Collonel,
How do thy companies fill now?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You are merry Sir,
You intend a ſafer war at home belike now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do not think I ſhall fight much this year Collonel,
I find my ſelf given to my eaſe a little,
I care not if I ſell my fooliſh company,
They are things of hazard.

sp.speaker: Alon,
sp.l: How it angers me,
This fellow at firſt ſight ſhould win a Lady,
A rich young wench, and I that have conſum'd
My time and art in ſearching out their ſubtilities,
Like a fool'd Alchymiſt blow up my hopes ſtill?
When ſhall we come to thy houſe and be freely merry?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: When I have manag'd her a little more,
I have an houſe to entertain an Army.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: If thy wiſe be fair, thou wilt have few leſs
Come to thee.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: But where they'll get entertainment is the point Signier.
I beat no Drum.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You need none but her Taber,
May be I'le march after a month or two,
To get me a freſh ſtomach. I find Collonel
A wantonneſs in wealth, methinks I agree not with,
'Tis ſuch a trouble to be married too,
And have a thouſand things of great importance,
Jewels and plates, and fooleries moleſt me,
To have a mans brains whimſied with his wealth:
Before I walk'd contentedly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Miſtreſs Sir is ſick, becauſe you are abſent,
She mourns and will not eat.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Alas my Jewel,
Come I'le go with thee, Gentlemen your fair leaves,
You ſee I am ty'd a little to my yoke,
Pray pardon me, would ye had both ſuch loving wives.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I thank ye
For your old boots, never be blank Alonzo,
Becauſe this fellow has out-ſtript thy fortune;
Tell me ten days hence what he is, and how.
The gracious ſtate of matrimony ſtands with him,
Come, let's to dinner, when Magarita comes
We'l viſit both, it may be then your fortune.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Yes Madam, h'as been here this half hour,
I have queſtion'd him of all you can ask him,
And find him as fit as you had made the man,
He will make the goodlieſt ſhadow for iniquity.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Have ye ſearcht him Ladies?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: He's a man at all points, a likely man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Call him in Altea.
A man of a good preſence, pray ye come this way,
Of a luſty body, is his mind ſo tame?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Pray ye queſtion him, and if you find him not
Fit for your purpoſe, ſhake him off, there's no harm Done.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Can • ou love a young Lady? How he bluſhes!

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Leave •• ling of your hat, and hold your head up,
And ſpeak to'th' Lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes, I think I can,
I muſt be taught, I know not what it means Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You ſhall be taught, and can you when ſhe pleaſes
Go 〈…〉 and ſtay a week or two?
You ſhall have men and horſes to attend ye,
And money in your purſe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes I love riding,
And when I am from home I am ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Be as merry as you will: can you as handſomely
When you are ſent for back, come with obedience,
And do your duty to the Lady loves you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes ſure, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And when you ſee her friends here,
Or noble Kinſmen, can you entertain
Their ſervants in the Celler, and be buſied,
And hold your Peace, what e're you ſee or hear of?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Twere fit I were hang'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let me try your kiſſes,
How the fool ſhakes, I will not eat ye Sir,
Bethrew my heart he kiſſes wondrous manly,
Can ye do any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed I know not;
But if your Ladiſhip will pleaſe to inſtruct me,
Sure I ſhall learn.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You ſhall then be inſtructed.
If I ſhould be this Lady that affects ye,
Nay ſay I marry ye?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Hark to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What money have ye?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None Madam, nor friends,
I would do any thing to ſerve your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You muſt not look to be my Maſter Sir.
Not talk I'th houſe as tho you wore the Breeches,
No, nor command in any thing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I • ill not,
Alas I am not able, I have no wit Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Nor do not labour to arrive at any,
'T will ſpoil your head, I take ye upon charity,
And like a ſervant ye muſt be unto me,
As I behold your duty I ſhall love ye,
And as you obſerve me, I may chance lye with ye,
Can you mark theſe?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes indeed forſooth.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: There is one thing,
That if I take ye in I put ye from me,
Utterly from me, you muſt not be ſawcy,
No, nor at any time familiar with me,
Scarce know me, when I call ye not.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will not, alas I never knew my ſelf ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Nor muſt not now.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'le be a Dog to pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Indeed you muſt fetch and carry as I appoint ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I were to blame elſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Kiſs me again; a ſtrong fellow,
There is a vigor in his lips: if you ſee me
Kiſs any other, twenty in an hour Sir,
You muſt not ſtart, nor be offended.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No, if you kiſs a thouſand I ſhall be contented,
It will the better teach me how to pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: I told ye Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis the man I wiſht for; the leſs you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'le never ſpeak again Madam.
But when you charge me, then I'le ſpeak ſoftly too.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Get me a Prieſt, I'le wed him inſtantly,
But when you are married Sir, you muſt wait
Upon me, and ſee you obſerve my laws.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Elſe you ſhall hang me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'le give you better clothes when you deſerve 'em,
Come in, and ſerve for witneſs.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We ſhall Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And then away to th' City preſently,
I'le to my new houſe and new company.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A thouſand Crowns are thine, and I am a made man.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Do not break out too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know my time wench.

div.stage: Enter Clara, and Eſtifania with a paper.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: What, have you caught him?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And do you find him
A man of thoſe hopes that you aim'd at?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Yes too,
And the moſt kind man, and the ableſt alſo
To give a wife content, he is ſound as old wine,
And to his ſoundneſs riſes on the Pallat,
And there's the man; find him rich too Clara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Haſt thou married him?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: What doſt thou think I fiſh without a bait wench?
I bob for fools? he is mine own, I have him,
I told thee what would tickle him like a •• oue,
And as I caſt it ſo I caught him daintily,
And all he has I have ſtow'd at my devotion.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Does thy Lady know this? ſhe is coming now to town,
Now to live here in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Let her come,
She ſhall be welcom, I am prepar'd for her,
She is mad ſure if ſhe be angry at my fortune,
For what I have made bold.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Doſt thou not love him?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Yes intirely well,
As long as there he ſtays and looks no farther
Into my ends, but when he doubts, I hate him,
And that wiſe hate will teach me how to cozen him:
How to decline their wives, and curb their manners,
To put a ſtern and ſtrong reyn to their natures,
And holds he is an Aſs not worth acquaintance,
That cannot mould a Devil to obedience,
I owe him a good turn for theſe opinions,
And as I find his temper I may pay him.
O here he is, now you ſhall ſee a kind man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: My Eſtifania, ſhall we to dinner lamb?
I know thou ſtay'ſt for me.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I cannot eat elſe.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I never enter but methinks a Paradice
Appears about me.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: You are welcom to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I think I have the ſweeteſt ſeat in Spain wench,
Methinks the richeſt too, we'll eat i'th' garden
In one o'th' arbours, there 'tis cool and pleaſant,
And have our wine cold in the running fountain.
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: A friend of mine Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Of what breeding?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: What buſineſs has ſhe?
Is ſhe a learned woman i'th' Mathematicks,
Can ſhe tell fortunes?

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: More than I know Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Or has ſhe e're a letter from a kinſwoman,
That muſt be delivered in my abſence wife,
Or comes ſhe from the Doctor to ſalute ye,
And learn your health? ſhe looks not like a Confeſſor.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: What needs all this, why are you troubled Sir,
What do you ſuſpect, ſhe cannot cuckold ye,
She is a woman Sir, a very woman.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Your very woman may do very well Sir
Toward the matter, for though ſhe cannot perform it
In her own perſon, ſhe may do it by Proxie,
Your rareſt jugglers work ſtill by conſpiracy.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Cry ye mercy husband, you are jealous then.
And happily ſuſpect me.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No indeed wife,

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Methinks you ſhould not till you have more cauſe
Andclearer too: I am ſure you have heard ſay husband,
A woman forced will free her ſelf through Iron.
A happy, calm, and good wife diſcontented
May be taught tricks.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: No, no, I do but jeſt with ye.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: To morrow friend I'le ſee you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I ſhall leave ye
Till then, and pray all may go ſweetly with ye.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Why where's this girl, who's at the door?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Who knocks there?
Is't for the King ye come, you knock ſo boiſterouſly?
Look to the door.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: My Lady, as I live Miſtris, my Lady's come,
She's at the door, I peept through, and I ſaw her,
And a ſtately company of Ladies with her.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: This was a week too ſoon, but I muſt meet with her,
And ſet a new wheel going, and a ſubtile one,
Muſt blind this mighty Mars, or I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: What are they at door?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Such my Michael
As you may bleſs the day they enter'd there,
Such for our good.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.l: Nay 'twill be better
If you will let me but diſpoſe the buſineſs,
And be a ſtranger to it, and not diſturb me,
What have I now to do but to advance your fortune?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Do, I dare truſt thee, I am aſham'd I am angry,
I find thee a wiſe young wife.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I'le wiſe your worſhip
Before I leave ye, pray ye walk by and ſay nothing,
Only ſalute them, and leave the reſt to me Sir,
I was born to make ye a man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: The Rogue ſpeaks heartily,
Her good will colours in her cheeks, I am born to love her,
I muſt be gentler to theſe tender natures,
A Soldiers rude harſh words befit not Ladies,
Nor muſt we talk to them as we talk to
Our Officers, I'le give her way, for 'tis for me ſhe
Works now, I am husband, heir, and all ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Enter
sp.l: Margarita, Eſtifania, Leon, Altea, and Ladies.
Who are theſe, what flanting things, a woman
Of rare preſence! excellent fair, this is too big
For a bawdy houſe, too open ſeated too.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: My Husband, Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You have gain'd a proper man.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: What e're I am, I am your ſervant Lady.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Sir, be rul'd now,
And I ſhall make ye rich, this is my couſin,
That Gentleman dotes on her, even to death, ſee how he obſerves her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: She is a goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: She is a mirrour,
But ſhe is poor, ſhe were for a Princes ſide elſe,
This houſe ſhe has brought him too as to her own,
And preſuming upon me, and upon my courteſie;
Conceive me ſhort, he knows not but ſhe is wealthy,
Or if he did know otherwiſe, 'twere all one,
He is ſo far gone.

sp.speaker: Perez
sp.l: Forward, ſhe has a rare face.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: This we muſt carry with diſcretion Husband,
And yield unto her for four days.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Yield our houſe up, our goods and wealth?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: All this is but in ſeeming,
To milk the lover on, do you ſee this writing,
200 l. a year when they are married
Has ſhe ſealed to for our good; the time's unfit now,
I'le ſhew it you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: All the houſe?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: All, all, and we'll remove too, to confirm him,
They'll into th' country ſuddenly again
After they are matcht, and then ſhe'll open to him.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: The whole poſſeſſion wife? look what you do,
A part o'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: No, no, they ſhall have all,
And take their pleaſure too, 'tis for our 'vantage.
Why, what's four days? had you a Siſter Sir,
A Niece or Miſtriſs that required this courteſie,
And ſhould I make a ſcruple to do you good?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: If eaſily it would come back.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I ſwear Sir,
As eaſily as it came on, is't not a pity
To let ſuch a Gentlewoman for a little help—
You give away no houſe.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Clear but that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I'le put the writings into your hand.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Well then.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: And you ſhall keep them ſafe.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied; wou'd I had the wench ſo too.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: When ſhe has married him,
So infinite his love is linkt unto her,
You, I, or any one that helps at this pinch
May have Heaven knows what.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'le remove the goods ſtraight,
And take ſome poor houſe by, 'tis but for four days.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I have a poor old friend; there we'll be.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: 'Tis well then.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Go handſom off, and leave the houſe clear.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: That little ſtuff we'll uſe ſhall follow after;
And a boy to guide ye, peace and we are made both.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Come, let's go in, are all the rooms kept ſweet wench?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: They are ſweet and neat.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why where's your Husband?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Gone Madam.
When you come to your own he muſt give place Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well, ſend your joy, you would not let me know't,
Yet I ſhall not forget ye.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Thank your Ladyſhip.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: ARE you at eaſe now, is your heart at reſt,
Now you have got a ſhadow, an umbrella
To keep the ſcorching worlds opinion
From your fair credit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I am at peace Altea,
If he continue but the ſame he ſhews,
And be a maſter of that ignorance
He outwardly profeſſes, I am happy,
The pleaſure I ſhall live in and the freedom
Without the ſquint eye of the law upon me,
Or prating liberty of tongues, that envy.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: You are a made woman.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But if he ſhould prove now
A crafty and diſſembling kind of Husband.
One read in knavery, and brought up in the art
Of Villany conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Altca.
sp.l: My life, an innocent.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: That's it I aim at;
That's it I hope too, then I am ſure I rule him,
For innocents are like obedient Children,
Brought up under a hard Mother-in law, a cruel,
Who being not us'd to Break-faſts and Collations,
When they have courſe bread offer'd 'em, are thankful,
And take it for a favour too. Are the rooms
Made ready to entertain my friends? I long to dance now
And to be wanton; let me have a ſong, is the great Couch up
The Duke of Meaina ſent?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: 'Tis up and ready.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And Day-beds in all Chambers?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: In all, Lady;
Your houſe is nothing now but various pleaſures,
The Gallants begin to gaze too.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let 'em gaze on,
I was brought up a Courtier high and happy,
And Company is my delight, and Courtſhip,
And handſom ſervants at my will: where's my good Husband
Where does he wait?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: He knows his diſtance, Madam,
I warrant ye, he is buſy in the Cellar
Amongſt his fellow ſervants, or aſleep,
Till your Command awake him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis well Altea,
It ſhould be ſo, my ward I muſt preſerve him:
Who ſent for him, how dare he come uncall'd for,
His bonnet on too?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Sure he ſees you not.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: How ſcornful he looks!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are all the Chambers
Deckt and adorn'd thus for my Ladies pleaſure?
New hangings every hour for entertainment,
And 〈…〉 bought, new Jewels to give luſtre?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are, and yet there muſt be more and richer,
It is 〈◊〉 will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hum, is it 〈◊〉 'tis excellent,
It is her will too▪ to have Feaſts and Banquets;
Revels and Maſqu • s.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: She ever lov'd 'em dearly,
And we •• ll have the braveſt houſe kept now Sir,
I muſt 〈◊〉 ye Maſter ſhe has warn'd me,
Nor muſt not put my Hat off to 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis no faſhion,
What though I be her Husband, I am your fellow,
I may cut firſt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: That's as you ſhall deſerve Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And when I lye with her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: May be I'le light ye,
On the ſame point you may do me that ſervice.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.l: Madam, the Duke Medina with ſome Captains
Will come to dinner and have ſent rare Wine,
And their beſt ſervices.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: They ſhall be welcom:
See all be ready in the nobleſt faſhion,
The houſe perfum'd, now I ſhall take my pleaſure,
And not my neighbour Juſtice maunder at me.
Go, get your beſt cloaths on, but till I call ye,
Be ſure you be not ſeen, dine with the Gentlewomen,
And behave your ſelf cleanly Sir, 'tis for my credit.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: Madam, the Lady Julia.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That's a bawd,
A three pil'd bawd, bawd major to the Army.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.l: His brought her Coach to wait upon your Ladiſhip,
And to be inform'd if you will take the air this morning.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The neat air of her Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Tell her no, i'th' afternoon I'le call on her.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why are not you gone to prepare your ſelf,
May be you ſhall be ſewer to the fire courſe,
A portly preſence: Altea he looks lean
'Tis a waſh knave, he will not keep his fleſh well.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: A • illing, Madam, one that needs no ſpurring.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Faith Madam, in my little underſtanding,
You had better entertain your honeſt neighbours,
Your friends about ye, that may ſpeak well of ye,
And give a worthy mention of your bounty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: How now, what's this?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis only to perſwade ye,
Courtiers are but fickle things to deal withal,
A kind of •• rch-p • ne that will not •• ſt Madam,
An egg and pepper goes farther than their potions,
And a well built body, a poor parſnip
Will play his prize above their ſtrong potabiles.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: The fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He that ſhall counſel Ladies
That have both liquoriſh and ambitious eyes,
Is either mad,—or drunk, let him ſpeak Goſpel.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: He breaks out modeſtly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Pray be not angry,
My indiſcretion has made bold to tell ye,
What you'l find true.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Thou dareſt not talk.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not much Madam.
You have a tye upon your ſervants tongue,
H • dares not be ſo bold as reaſon bids him,
'T were fit there were a ſtronger on your temper.
Ne're look ſo ſtern upon me, I am your Husband,
But what are Husbands? read the new worlds wonders.
Such Husbands as this monſtrous world produces,
And you will ſcarce find ſuch deformities:
They are ſhadows to conceal your venial vertues,
Sails to your mills, that grind with all occaſions,
Balls that lye by you, to waſh out your ſtains,
And bills nail'd up with horn before your ſtories,
To rent out laſt.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Do you hear him talk?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have done Madam.
An Oxe once ſpoke, as learned men deliver,
Shortly I ſhall be ſuch, then I'le ſpeak wonders,
Till when I tye my ſelf to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Firſt I'le unty my-ſelf, did you mark the Gentleman,
How boldly and how ſawcily he talk'd
And how unlike the lump I took him for,
The piece of ignorant dough, he ſtood up to me
And mated my commands, this was your providence,
Your wiſdom, to elect this Gentleman,
Your excellent forecaſt in the man, your knowledge,
What think ye now?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: I think him an Aſſe ſtill,
This boldneſs ſome of your people have blown
Into him, this wiſdom too with ſtrong wine,
'Tisa Tyrant, and a Philoſopher alſo, and finds
Out reaſons.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.l: I'le have my Cellar lockt, no ſchool kept there,
Nor no diſcovery. I'le turn my drunkards,
Such as are underſtanding in their draughts,
And diſpute learn •• ly the whyes and wherefores,
To graſs immediately, I'le keep all fools,
Sober or drunk, ſtill fools, that ſhall know nothing,
Nothing belongs to mankind, but obedience,
And ſuch a hand I'le keep over this Husband.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: He will fall again, my life he cryes by this time,
Keep him from drink, he has a high conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Shall I wear my new ſute Madam?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No your old clothes,
And get you into the country preſently,
And ſee my hawks well train'd, you ſhall have Victuals,
Such are are fit for ſawcy palats Sir,
And lodgings with the Hindes, it is too good too.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Good Madam be not ſo rough, with repentance,
You ſee now he is come round again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſee not what I expect of ſee.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You ſhall ſee Madam, if it ſhall pleaſe your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: He's humbled,
Forgive good Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well go get you handſome,
And let me hear no more.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Have ye yet no feeling?
I'le pinch ye to the bones then my proud Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.l: See you preſerve him thus upon my favour,
You know his temper, tye him to the grindſtone,
The next rebellion I'le be rid of him,
I'le have no needy Raſcals I tye to me,
Diſpute my life: come in and ſee all handſom.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: I hope too ſee you ſo too, I have wrought ill elſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Shall I never return to mine own houſe again?
We are lodg'd here in the miſerableſt dog-hole,
A Conjurers circle gives content above it,
A hawks new is a princely palace to it,
We have a bed no bigger then a basket,
And there we lye like Butter clapt together,
And ſweat our ſelves to ſawce immediately;
The fumes are infinite inhabit here too;
And to that ſo thick, they cut like Marmalet,
So various too, they'l poſe a Gold-finder:
Never return to mine own paradice?
Why VVife I ſay, why Eſtifania.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: [within.] I am going preſently.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Make haſte good Jewel.
I am like the people that live in the ſweet Iſlands:
I dye, I dye, if I ſtay but one day more here;
My lungs are rotten with the damps that riſe,
And I cough nothing now but ſtinks of all ſorts;
The Inhabitants we have, are two ſtarv'd Rats,
For they are not able to maintain a Cat here,
And thoſe appear as fearful as two Devils;
They have eat a map of the whole World up already,
And if we ſtay a night we are gone for Company.
There's an old woman that's now grown to marble,
Dry'd in this Brick hill, and ſhe ſets i'th' Chimny,
VVhich is but 3 Tiles rais'd like a houſe of Cards,
There is a young thing too that Nature meant
For a Maid-ſervant, but 'tis now a monſter,
She has a husk about her like a Cheſnut,
VVith buſineſs, and living under the line here,
And theſe two make a hollow ſound together,
Like Frogs or VVinds between two doors that murmur.
Mercy deliver me. O are you come VVife,
Shall we be free again?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I am now going,
And you ſhall preſently to your own houſe Sir,
The remembrance of this ſmall vexation
Will be argument of mirth for ever.
By that time you have ſaid your Oriſons,
And broke your faſt, I ſhall be back and ready,
To uſher you to your old content, your fredom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Break my neck rather, is there any thing here to eat
But one another, like a race of Cannibals?
A piece of butter'd Wall you think is excellent,
Let's have our houſe again immediately,
And pray ye take heed unto the furniture,
None be imbe • zel'd.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Not a pin I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: And let 'em inſtantly depart.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: They ſhall both.
There's reaſon in all courteſies, they muſt both,
For by this time I know • he has acquainted him,
And has provided to, ſhe ſent me word Sir,
And will give over gracefully unto you.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'le walk i'th' Church yard;
The dead cannot offend more than theſe living,
An hour hence I'le expect ye.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I'le not fail Sir.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: And do you hear, let's have a handſome dinner,
And ſee all things be decent as they have been,
And let me have a ſtrong Bath to reſtore me,
I ſtink like a ſtall-fiſh ſham • les, or an Oyl-ſhop.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You ſhall have all, which ſome interpret nothing,
I'le ſend ye people for the Trunks afore-hand,
And for the ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Let em be known and honeſt,
And do my ſervice to your Niece.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir,
But if I come not at my hour, come thither,
That they may give you thanks for your fair courteſie,
And pray ye be brave for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I obſerve ye.

div.stage: Enter Juan de Caſtro, Sancho, and Cacaiogo.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Thou art very brave.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I have reaſon, I have money.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Is money reaſon?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Yes, and rhime too Captain,
If ye have no money y're an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Ye have manners, ever thank him that has money.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Wilt thou lend me any?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Not a farthing Captain,
Captains are caſual things.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Why ſo are all men, thou ſhalt have my bond.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Nor bonds nor fetters Captain,
My money is mine, I make no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What doſt thou do with it?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Put it to pious uſes,
Buy Wine and Wenches, and undo young Coxcombs
That would undo me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Are thoſe Hoſpitals?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I firſt provide to fill my Hoſpitals
With Creatures of mine own, that I know wretched,
And then I build: thoſe are more bound to pray for me:
Beſides, I keep th'inheritance in my Name ſtill.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: A provident Charity; are you for the Wars, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I am not poor enough to be a Souldier,
Nor have I faith enough to ward a Bullet;
This is no lining for a Trench, I take it.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Ye have ſaid wiſely.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Had you but my money,
You would ſwear it Collonel, I had rather drill at home
A hundred thouſand Crowns, and with more honour,
Than exerciſe ten thouſand Fools with nothing;
A wiſe man ſafely feeds, Fools cut their fingers.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: A right State Uſurer; why doſt thou not marry,
And live a reverend Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Is't not nobler to command a reverend Juſtice, than to be one?
And for a Wife, what need I marry, Captain,
When every courteous fool that owes me money.
Owes me his Wife too, to appeaſe my fury?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Wilt thou go to dinner with us?

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I will go, and view the Pearl of Spain, the Orient
Fair One, the rich One too, and I will be reſpected,
I bear my Patent here, I will talk to her,
And when your Captainſhips ſhall ſtand aloof,
And pick your Noſes, I will pick the purſe
Of her affection.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: The Duke dines there to day too, the Duke of Medina.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Let the King dine there,
He owes me money, and ſo far's my Creature,
And certainly I may make bold with mine own, Captain?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Thou wilt eat monſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Like a true born Spaniard,
Eat as I were in England where the Beef grows,
And I will drink abundantly, and then
Talk ye as wantonly as Ovid did,
To ſtir the intellectuals of the Ladies;
I learnt it of my Father's amorous Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: If we ſhould play now, you muſt ſupply me.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: You muſt pawn a Horſe Troop,
And then have at ye Collonel.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Come, let's go:
This Raſcal will make rare ſport; how the Ladies
Will laugh at him?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: If I light on him I'll make his Purſe ſweat too.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Will ye lead, Gentlemen?

div.stage: Enter Perez, an old Woman, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, pray ye come out, and let me underſtand ye,
And tune your pipe a little higher, Lady;
I'll hold you faſt, rub, how came my Trunks open?
And my Goods gone, what Pick-lock Spirit?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Ha, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Goods again, how came my Trunks all open?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Are your Trunks open?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes, and Cloaths gone,
And Chains, and Jewels: how ſhe ſmells like hung Beef,
The Palſey, and Pick-locks; fye, how ſhe belches,
The Spirit of Garlick.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Where's your Gentlewoman?
The young fair Woman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What's that to my queſtion?
She is my Wife, and gone about my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Is ſhe your Wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes Sir, is that wonder?
In the name of Wife unknown here.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Is ſhe truly, truly your Wife?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I think ſo, for I married her;
It was no Viſion ſure!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: She has the Keys, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I know ſhe has, but who has all my Goods, Spirit?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: If you be married to that Gentlewoman,
You are a wretched man, ſhe has twenty Husbands.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: She tells you true.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: And ſhe has cozen'd all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Devil ſhe has! I had a fair houſe with her,
That ſtands hard by, and furniſht royally.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: You are cozen'd too, 'tis none of hers, good Gentleman

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: The Lady Margarita, ſhe was her Servant,
And kept the houſe, but going from her, Sir,
For ſome lewd tricks ſhe plaid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Plague o' the Devil,
Am Ii'th full meridian of my wiſdom
Cheated by a ſtale Quean! what kind of Lady
Is that that owes the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: A young ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Of a low ſtature?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: She is indeed but little, but ſhe is wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I feel I am cozen'd;
Now I am ſenſible I am undone,
This is the very Woman ſure, that Couſin
She told me would entreat but for four days,
To make the houſe hers; I am entreated ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: When ſhe went out this morning, that I ſaw, Sir,
She had two Women at the door attending,
And there ſhe gave 'em things and loaded 'em,
But what they were—I heard your Trunks to open,
If they be yours?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: They were mine while they were laden,
But now they have caſt their Calves, they are not worth
Owning: was ſhe her Miſtreſs ſay you?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Her own Miſtreſs, her very Miſtreſs, Sir, and all you ſaw
About, and in that houſe was hers.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No Plate, no Jewels, nor no Hangings?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not a farthing, ſhe is poor, Sir, a poor ſhifting thing.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No money?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Abominable poor, as poor as we are,
Money as rare to her unleſs ſhe ſteal it,
But for one civil Gown her Lady gave her,
She may go bare, good Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am mad now,
I think I am as poor as ſhe, I am wide elſe,
One civil Sute I have left too, and that's all,
And if ſhe ſteal that, ſhe muſt fley me for it;
Where does ſhe uſe?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: You may find truth as ſoon,
Alas, a thouſand conceal'd corners, Sir, ſhe lurks in.
And here ſhe gets a fleece, and there another,
And lives in miſts and ſmoaks where none can find her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is ſhe a Whore too?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Little better, Gentleman, I dare not ſay ſhe is ſo Sir, becauſe
She is yours, Sir, theſe 5 years ſhe has firkt
A pretty living,
Until ſhe came to ſerve; I fear he will knock my
Brains out for lying.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She has ſerv'd me faithfully,
A Whore and Thief? two excellent moral learnings
In one She Saint, I hope to ſee her legend.
Have I been fear'd for my diſcoveries,
And courted by all women to conceal 'em?
Have I ſo long ſtudied the art of this Sex,
And read the warnings to young Gentlemen?
Have I profeſt to tame the pride of Ladies,
And make 'em bear all teſts, and am I trickt now?
Caught in mine own nooze? here's a Royal left yet,
There's for your lodging and your meat for this week.
A ſilk worm lives at a more plentiful ordinary,
And ſleeps in a ſweeter Box; farewel great Grandmother,
If I do find you were an acceſſary,
'Tis but the cutting off wo ſmoaky minutes,
I'll hang ye preſently.

sp.speaker: Old. Wom.
sp.l: And I deſerve it, I tell but truth.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Not I, I am an Aſs, Mother.

sp.speaker: Enter the Duke of
sp.l: Medina, Juan de Caſtro, Alonzo, Sancho, Caca • ogo.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A goodly houſe.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: And richly furniſht too Sir.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: Hung wantonly, I like that preparation,
It ſtirs the blood unto a hopeful Banquet,
And intimates the Miſtreſs free and jovial,
I love a houſe where pleaſure prepares welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now Cacafogo, how like you this manſion?
'Twere a brave pawn.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I ſhall be maſter of it,
'Twas built for my bulk, the rooms are wide and ſpacious,
Airy and full of eaſe, and that I love well,
I'll tell you when I taſt the Wine, my Lord,
〈…〉 the height of her Table with my Stomach,
How my affections ſtand to the young Lady.

div.stage: Enter Margarita, Altea, Ladies, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All welcom to your Grace, and to theſe Soldiers,
You honour my poor houſe with your fair preſence,
Thoſe few ſlight pleaſures that inhabit here, Sir,
I do beſeech your Grace command, they are yours,
Your ſervant but preſerves 'em to delight ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think ye Lady, I am bold to viſit ye,
Once more to bleſs mine eyes with your ſweet Beauty,
'T has been a long night ſince you left the Court,
For till I ſaw you now, no day broke to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Bring in the Dukes meat.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: She is moſt excellent.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Moſt admirable fair as e'r I lookt upon,
I had rather command her than my Regiment.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I'll have a ſting, 'tis but a thouſand Duckets,
Which I can cozen up again in ten days,
And ſome few Jewels to juſtify my knavery,
Say, I ſhould marry her, ſhe'll get more money
Than all my Uſury, put my kna •• ry to it,
She appears the moſt infallible way of Purchaſe,
I cou'd wiſh her a ſize or two ſtronger for the encounter,
For I am like a Lion where I lay hold,
But theſe Lambs will endure a plaguy load,
And never bleat neither, that Sir, time has taught us.
I am ſo vertuous now, I cannot ſpeak to her,
The arrant'ſt ſhamefac'd Aſs, I broil away too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, where's this dinner?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis not ready, Madam,
Nor ſhall not be until I know the Gueſts too,
Nor are they fairly welcom till I bid 'em.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Is not this my Alferes? he looks another thing;
Are miracles afoot again?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why, Sirrah, why Sirrah, you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I hear you, ſaucy woman,
And as you are my VVife, command your abſence,
And know your duty, 'tis the Crown of modeſty,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your VVife?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes good my Lord, I am her Husband,
And pray take notice that I claim that honour,
And will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: If thou be'ſt her Husband,
I am determin'd thou ſhalt be my Cuckold.
I'll be thy faithful friend.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Peace, dirt and dunghil,
I will not loſe my anger on a Raſcal,
Provoke me more, I'll beat thy blown body
Till thou rebound'ſt again like a Tennis-ball.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: This is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Is this the fellow
That had the patience to become a Fool,
A flurted Fool, and on a ſudden break,
As if he would ſhew a wonder to the VVorld,
Both in Bravery, and Fortune too?
I much admire the man; I am aſtoniſht.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll be divorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You ſhall not,
You ſhall not have ſo much will to be wicked.
I am more tender of your honour, Lady,
And of your Age; you took me for a ſhadow;
You took me to gloſs over your diſcredit,
To be your fool, you had thought you had ſound a Coxcomb;
I am innocent of any foul diſhonour I mean to ye.
Only I will be known to be your Lord now,
And be a fair one too, or I will fall for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do command ye from me, thou poor fellow,
Thou cozen'd fool.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou cozen'd fool 'tis not ſo,
I will not be commanded: I am above ye:
You may divorce me from your favour, Lady,
But from your ſtate you never ſhall, I'll hold that
And then maintain your wantonneſs, I'll wink at it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Am I braved thus in my own houſe?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, Madam,
You are deceiv'd, I am Lord of it, I rule it and all that's in't;
You have nothing to do here, Madam;
But as a ſervant to ſweep clean the Lodgings,
And at my farther will to do me ſervice,
And ſo I'll keep it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As you love me, give way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It ſhall be better,
I will give none, Madam,
I ſtand upon the ground of mine own honour
And will maintain it, you ſhall know me now
To be an underſtanding feeling man,
And ſenſible of what a Woman aims at,
A young proud woman that has will to ſail with,
And itching woman, that her blood provokes too,
I caſt my Cloud off, and appear my ſelf,
The maſter of this little piece of miſchief,
And I will put a Spell about your feet, Lady,
They ſhall not wander but where I give way now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this the fellow that the people pointed at,
For the meer ſign of man, the walking image?
He ſpeaks wondrous highly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As a Husband ought, Sir,
In his own houſe, and it becomes me well too,
I think your Grace would grieve if you were put to it
To have a Wife or Servant of your own,
(For VVives are reckon'd in the rank of Servants,)
Under your own roof to command ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Brave, a ſtrange Converſion, thou ſhalt lead
In chief now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is there no difference betwixt her and you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Not now, Lord, my fortune makes me even,
And as I am an honeſt man, I am nobler.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Get me my Coach.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Let me ſee who dares get it
Till I command, I'll make him draw your Coach too,
And eat your Coach, (which will be hard diet)
That executes your VVill, or take your Coach, Lady,
I give you liberty, and take your people
VVhich I turn off, and take your VVill abroad with ye,
Take all theſe freely, but take me no more,
And ſo farewel.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, you ſhall not carry it
So bravely off, you ſhall not wrong a Lady
In a high huffing ſtrain, and think to bear it,
We ſtand not by as bawds to your brave fury,
To ſee a Lady weep.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They are tears of anger, beſeech ye note 'em, not worth pity,
Wrung from her rage, becauſe her Will prevails not,
She would ſwound now if ſhe could not cry,
Elſe they were excellent, and I ſhould grieve too,
But falling thus, they ſhow nor ſweet nor orient.
Put up my Lord, this is oppreſſion,
And calls the Sword of Juſtice to relieve me,
The law to lend her hand, the King to right me,
All which ſhall underſtand how you provoke me,
In mine own houſe to brave me, is this princely?
Then to my Guard, and if I ſpare your Grace,
And do not make this place your Monument,
Too rich a Tomb for ſuch a rude behaviour,
I have a Cauſe will kill a thouſand of ye, mercy forſake me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Hold fair Sir, I beſeech ye,
The Gentleman but pleads his own right nobly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He that dares ſtrike againſt the Husbands freedom.
The Husbands 〈◊〉 ſtick to him, a tam'd Cuckold,
His Wi • e be fair and young, but moſt diſhoneſt,
Moſt impudent, and have no feeling of it,
No conſcience to reclaim her from a Monſter,
Let her lye by him like a flattering ruine,
And at one inſtant kill both Name and Honour,
Let him be lo • t, • o eye to weep his end,
Nor find • o •• rth that's baſe enough to bury him.
Now Sir, 〈…〉 , I am ready to oppoſe ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have •• tter thought, I pray Sir uſe your Wiſe well.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 own humanity will teach me that, Sir,
And now you are all welcom, all, and we'll to dinner,
This is my Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'll croſs your joy yet.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I have ſeen a miracle, hold thine own, Souldier.
Sure they dare fight in fire that conque • Women.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: H'as beaten all my looſe thoughts out of me.
As if he had threſht 'em out o'th' husk.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Save ye, which is the Lady of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That's ſhe, Sir, that pretty Lady,
If you would ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Don Michael, Leon, another darer come.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray do not know me, I am full of buſineſs.
When I have more time I'll be merry with ye.
It is the woman: good Madam, tell me truly,
Had you a Maid call'd Eſtifania?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes truly, had I.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was ſhe a Maid do you think?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I dare not ſwear for her,
For ſhe had but a ſcant fame.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was ſhe your Kinſwoman?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Not that I ever knew, now I look better
I think you married her, 'give you joy, Sir,
You may reclaim her, 'twas a wild young Girl.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Give me a halter: is not this houſe mine, Madam?
VVas not ſhe owner of it, pray ſpeak truely?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No, certainly, I am ſure my money paid for it,
And I ne'r remember yet I gave it you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Hangings and the Plate too?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: All are mine, Sir,
And every thing you ſee about the building,
She only kept my houſe when I was abſent,
And ſo ill kept it, I was weary of her.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: VVhat a Devil ails he?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: He's poſſeſt I'll aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: VVhere is your Maid?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Do not you know that have her.
She is yours now, why ſhould I look after her?
Since that firſt hour I came I never ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I ſaw her later, would the Devil had had her,
It is all true I find, a wild-fire take her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Is thy Wife with Child, Don Michael? thy excellent Wiſe:
Art thou a Man yet?

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: When ſhall we come and viſit thee?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: And eat ſome rare fruit? thou haſt admirable Orchards,
You are ſo jealous now, pox o' your jealouſy,
How ſcurvily you look!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Prithee▪ leave fooling,
I am in no humour now to fool and prattle,
Did ſhe ne'r play the wag with you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes many times, ſo often that I was aſham'd to keep her,
But I forgave her, Sir, in hope ſhe would mend ſtill,
And had not you o'th' inſtant married her,
I had put her off.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thank ye, I am bleſt ſtill,
Which way ſoe're I turn I am a made man,
Miſerably gull'd beyond recovery.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: You'll ſtay and dine?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Certain I cannot, Captain,
Hark in thine ear, I am the arrantſt Puppy,
The miſerableſt Aſs, but I muſt leave ye,
I am in haſte, in haſte, bleſs you, good Madam.
And you prove as good as my Wife.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: VVill you come near Sir, will your Grace but honour me,
And taſte our dinner? you are nobly welcom,
All anger's paſt I hope, and I ſhall ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Thou art the ſtock of men, and I admire thee]

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'Ll go to a Conjurer but I'll find this Pol cat,
This pilfering whore: a plague of Vails, I cry,
And covers for the impudence of VVomen,
Their ſanctity in ſhow will deceive Devils,
It is my evil Angel, let me bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Eſtif
sp.l: 'Tis he, I am caught, I muſt ſtand to it ſtoutly,
And ſhow no ſhake of fear, I ſee he is angry,
Vext at the uttermoſt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My worthy VVife,
I have been looking of your modeſty
All the Town over.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: My moſt noble Husband,
I am glad I have found ye, for in truth I am VVeary,
Weary and lame with looking out your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have been in Bawdy Houſes.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I believe you, and very lately too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Pray you pardon me,
To ſeek your Ladyſhip, I have been in Cellars,
In private Cellars, where the thirſty Bawds
Hear your Confeſſions; I have been at Plays,
To look you out amongſt the youthful Actors,
At Puppet-ſhews, you are Miſtreſs of the motions,
At Goſſippings I hearkened after you,
But amongſt thoſe Confuſions of lewd Tongues
There's no diſtinguiſhing beyond a Babel.
I was amongſt the Nuns becauſe you ſing well,
But they ſay yours are bawdy Songs, they mourn for ye,
And laſt I went to Church to ſeek you out,
'Tis ſo long ſince you were there, they have forgot you.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You have had a pretty progreſs, I'll tell mine now:
To look you out, I went to twenty Taverns.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And are you ſober?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Yes, I reel not yet, Sir,
VVhere I ſaw twenty drunk, moſt of 'em Soldiers,
There I had great hope to find you diſguis'd too.
From hence to th' dicing houſe, there I found
Quarrels needleſs and ſenceleſs, Sword and Pots, and Candleſticks,
Tables and Stools, and all in one confuſion,
And no man knew his friend. I left this Chaos,
And to the Chirurgeons went, he will'd me ſtay,
For ſays he learnedly, if he be tippled,
Twenty to one he whores, and then I hear of him,
If he be mad, he quarrels, then he comes too.
I ſought ye where no ſafe thing would have ventur'd,
Amongſt diſeaſes, baſe and vile, vile women,
For I remembred your old Roman axiom,
The more the danger, ſtill the more the honour:
Laſt, to your Confeſſor I came, who told me,
You were too proud to pray, and here I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She bears up bravely, and the Rogue is witty,
But I ſhall daſh it inſtantly to nothing.
Here leave me off our wanton languages
And now conclude we in a ſharper tongue.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: VVhy am I cozen'd?
VVhy am I abuſed?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou moſt vile, baſe, abominable—

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou ſtinking, overſtow'd, poor, pocky—

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do you eccho me?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and go before ye,
And round about ye, why do ye rail at me
For that that was your own ſin, your own knavery?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And brave me too?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You had beſt now draw your Sword, Captain?
Draw it upon a VVoman, do brave, Captain?
Upon your Wife, oh moſt renowned Captain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A Plague upon thee, anſwer me directly;
VVhy didſt thon marry me?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: To be my Husband;
I had thought you had had infinite, but I am cozen'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: VVhy didſt thou flatter me, and ſhew me wonders?
A houſe and riches, when they are but ſhadows,
Shadows to me?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Why did you work on me
(It was but my part to requite you, Sir)
With your ſtrong Souldiers wit, and ſwore you would bring me
So much in Chains, ſo much in Jewels, Husband,
So much in right rich Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou haſt 'em Raſcal;
I gave 'em to thy hands, my trunks and all,
And thou haſt open'd 'em, and ſold my treaſure.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Sir, there's your treaſure, ſell it to a Tinker
To mend old Kettles, is this noble Uſage?
Let all the world view here the Captain's treaſure,
A Man would think now, theſe were worthy matters;
Here's a ſhooing horn Chain gilt over, how it ſcenteth
Worſe than the mouldy dirty heel it ſerved for:
And here's another of a leſſer value,
So little I would ſhame to tye my Dog in't,
Theſe are my jointure, bluſh and ſave a labour,
Or theſe elſe will bluſh for ye.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A fire ſubtle ye, are ye ſo crafty?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Here's a goodly Jewel,
Did not you win this at Goletta, Captain,
Or took it in the field from ſome brave Baſſa,
How it ſparkles like an old Ladies Eyes,
And fills each room with light like a cloſe Lanthorn.
This would do rarely in an Abbey Window,
To cozen Pilgrims.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Prithee leave prating.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: And here's a Chain of Whitings eyes for Pearls,
A Muſcle-monger would have made a better.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, prithee Wife, my Cloaths, my Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I'll tell ye,
Your Cloaths are parallels to theſe, all counterfeit.
put theſe and them on, you are a Man of Copper,
A kind of Candleſtick; theſe you thought, my Husband,
To have cozen'd me withal, but I am quit with you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is there no houſe then, nor no grounds about it?
No Plate nor Hangings.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: There are none, ſweet Husband,
Shadow for ſhadow is as equal Juſtice.
Can you rail now? pray put up your fury, Sir,
And ſpeak great words, you are a Souldier, thunder.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will ſpeak little, I have plaid the fool,
And ſo I am rewarded.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: You have ſpoke well, Sir,
