And now I ſee you are ſo conformable
I'll heighten you again, go to your houſe,
They are packing to be gone, you muſt ſup there,
I'll meet ye, and bring Cloaths, and clean Shirts after,
And all things ſhall be well, I'll colt you once more,
And teach you to bring Copper.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Tell me one thing,
I do beſeech thee tell me, tell me truth, Wiſe,
However I forgive thee, art thou honeſt?
The Beldam ſwore.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I bid her tell you ſo, Sir.
It was my plot, alas my credulous Husband,
The Lady told you too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Moſt ſtrange things of thee.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Still 'twas my way, and all to try your ſufferance,
And ſhe denied the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She knew me not,
No, nor no title that I had.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: 'Twas well carried;
No more, I am right and ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I would believe thee.
But Heaven knows how my heart is, will ye follow me;

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I'll be there ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am fooled, yet dare not find it.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Go ſilly fool, thou mayſt be a good Souldier
In open field, but for our private ſervice
Thou art as Aſs, I'll make thee ſo, or miſs elſe.
Here comes another Trout that I muſt tickle,
And tickle daintily, I have loſt my end elſe.
May I crave your leave, Sir?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Prithee be anſwered, thou ſhalt crave no leave,
I am in my meditations, do not vex me,
A beaten thing, but this hour a moſt bruiſed thing,
That people had compaſſion on it, looked ſo,
The next Sir Palmerin, here's fine proportion,
An Aſs, and then an Elephant, ſweet Juſtice,
There's no way left to come at her now, no craving,
If money could come near, yet I would pay him;
I have a mind to make him a huge Cuckold,
And money may do much, a thouſand Duckets,
'Tis but the letting Blood of a rank Heir.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Pray you hear me.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I know thou haſt ſome wedding Ring to pawn now,
Of Silver and gilt, with a blind poſie in't,
Love and a Mill-horſe ſhould go round together,
Or thy Childs whiſtle, or thy Squirrels Chain,
I'll none of em, I would ſhe did but know me,
Or would this fellow had but uſe of money,
That I might come in any way.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I am gone, Sir,
And I ſhall tell the beauty ſent me to ye,
The Lady Margarita.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Stay I prithee,
What is thy Will? I turn me wholly to ye,
And talk now till thy tongue ake, I will hear ye.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: She would entreat you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: She ſhall command, Sir,
Let it be ſo, I beſeech thee, my ſweet Gentlewoman,
Do not forget thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: She does command then.
This courteſie, becauſe ſhe knows you are noble.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Your Miſtreſs by the way?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: My natural Miſtreſs,
Upon theſe Jewels, Sir, they are fair and rich,
And view 'em right.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: To doubt 'em, is an hereſie.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: A thouſand Duckets, 'tis upon neceſſity
Of preſent uſe, her Husband, Sir, is ſtubborn

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Long may he be ſo.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: She deſires withal a better knowledge of your parts and perſon,
And when you pleaſe to do her ſo much honour.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Come let's diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: In troth I have heard her ſay, Sir,
Of a fat man ſhe has not ſeen a ſweeter.
But in this buſineſs, Sir,

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Let's do it firſt
And then diſpute, the Ladies uſe may long for't.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: All ſecrecy ſhe would deſire, ſhe told me
How wiſe you are.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: We are not wiſe to talk thus,
Carry her the Gold, I'le look her out a Jewel,
Shall ſparkle like her eyes, and thee another,
Come prithee come, I long to ſerve thy Lady,
Long monſtrouſly, now valor I ſhall meet ye,
You that dare Dukes.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Green Gooſe you are now in ſippets.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Sanchio, Juan, Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He ſhall not have his will, I ſhall prevent him,
I have a toy here that will turn the tide,
And ſuddenly, and ſtrangely, here Don Juan,
Do you preſent it to him.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A fellow founded out of Charity,
And moulded to the height, contemn his maker,
Curb the free hand that fram'd him▪ This muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: That ſuch an Oyſter-ſhell ſhould hold a Pearl,
And of ſo rare a price in Priſon,
Was ſhe made to be the matter of her own undoing,
To let a ſlovenly unweildy fellow,
Unruly and ſelf-will'd, diſpoſe her beauties?
We ſuffer all Sir in this ſad Eclipſe,
She ſhould ſhine where ſhe might ſhow like her ſelf,
An abſolute ſweetneſs, to comfort thoſe admire her,
And thed her beams upon her friends.
We are gull'd all,
And all the world will grumble at your patience,
If ſhe be raviſh't thus.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ne'r fear it Sanchio,
We'll have her free again, and move at Court
In her clear orb: but one ſweet handſomneſs,
To bleſs this part of Spain, and have that ſlubber'd?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: 'Tis every good mans cauſe, and we muſt ſtir in it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'le warrant he ſhall be glad to pleaſe us,
And glad to ſhare too, we ſhall hear anon
A new ſong from him, let's attend a little.

div.stage: Enter Leon, and Juan, with a Commiſſion

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Collonel, I am bound to you for this nobleneſs,
I ſhould have been your Officer, 'tis true Sir;
And a proud man I ſhould have been to have ſerv'd you,
'Thas pleas'd the King out of his boundleſs favours,
To make me your companion; this Commiſſion
Gives me a Troop of Horſe.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I do rejoyce at it,
And am a glad man we ſhall gain your company,
I am ſure the King knows you are newly married,
And out of that reſpect gives you more time Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Within 4 days I am gone, ſo he commands me,
And 'tis not mannerly for me to argue it,
The time grows ſhorter ſtill, are your goods ready?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: They are aboard.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Do you hear ho, go carry this unto your Miſtris Sir,
And let her ſee how much the King has honour'd me,
Bid her be luſty, ſhe muſt make a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Go take down all the hangings,
And pack up all my Cloaths, my Plate and Jewels,
And all the furniture that's portable;
Sir when we lye in Garriſon, 'tis neceſſary
We keep a handſom Port, for the Kings honour;
And do you hear, let all your Ladies wardrobe
Be ſafely plac'd in Trunks, they muſt along too.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Whither muſt they go Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To the Wars, Lorenzo,
And you and all, I will not leave a turn-ſpit,
That has one dram of ſpleen againſt a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why then St. Jaques hey, you have made us all Sir,
And if we leave ye—does my Lady go too?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The ſtuff muſt go to morrow towards the Sea Sir,
All, all muſt go.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why Pedro, Vaſco, Dego,
Come help me, come come boys, Soldadoes, Comrades,
We'll fley theſe Beer-bellied Rogues, come away quickly.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: H'as taken a brave way to ſave his honour,
And croſs the Duke, now I ſhall love him dearly,
By the life of credit thou art a'noble Gentleman.

div.stage: Enter Margarita, led by two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Why how now wife, what, ſick at my preferment?
This is not kindly done.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No ſooner love ye,
Love ye entirely Sir, brought to conſider
The goodneſs of your mind and mine own duty,
But loſe you inſtantly, be divorc'd from ye?
This is a cruelty, I'le to the King▪
And tell him 'tis unjuſt to part two ſouls,
Two minds ſo nearly mixt.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By no means ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: If he were married but four days as I am.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He would hang himſelf the fifth, or fly his Country.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: He would make it Treaſon for that tongue that durſt
But talk of War, or any thing to vex him,
You ſhall not go.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt ſweet Wife.
What ſhall I loſe the King for a few kiſſes?
We'll have enough.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'le to the Duke my Couſin, he ſhall to th'King.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He did me this great office,
I thank his Grace for't, ſhould I pray him now,
To undo't again? fye 'twere a baſe diſcredit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Would I were able Sir to bear your company,
How willing ſhould I be then, and how merry!
I will not live alone.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Be in peace, you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What knocking's this? oh Heaven my head; why raſcals
I think the war's begun i'th' houſe already.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The preparation is, they are taking down,
And packing up the Hangings, Plate and Jewels,
And all thoſe furnitures that ſhall befit me
When I lye in Garriſon.

sp.speaker: Coachm.
sp.l: Muſt the Coach go too Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How will your Lady paſs to th' Sea elſe eaſily?
We ſhall find ſhipping for't there to tranſport it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I go? alas!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'le have a main care of ye,
I know ye are ſickly, he ſhall drive the eaſier,
And all accommodation ſhall attend ye.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Would I were able.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come I warrant ye,
Am not I with ye ſweet? are her Cloaths packt up,
And all her Linnen? give your Maids direction,
You know my time's but ſhort, and I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Let me have a Nurſe,
And all ſuch neceſſary people with me,
And an eaſie bark.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It ſhall not trot I warrant ye,
Curvet it may ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I am with Child Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: At four days warning? this is ſomething ſpeedy,
Do you conceive as our jennets do with a Weſt wind?
My heir will be an arrant fleet one Lady,
I'le ſwear you were a maid when I firſt lay with ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray do not ſwear, I thought I was a maid too,
But we may both be cozen'd in that point Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In ſuch a ſtrait point ſure I could not err Madam.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: This is another tenderneſs to try him,
Fetch her up now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You muſt provide a Cradle, and what a troubles that?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The Sea ſhall rock it,
'Tis the beſt nurſe; 'twill roar and rock together,
A ſwinging ſtorm will ſing you ſuch a lullaby.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Faith let me ſtay, I ſhall but ſhame ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And you were a thouſand ſhames you ſhall along with me,
At home I am ſure you'l prove a million,
Every man carries the bundle of his ſins
Upon his own back, you are mine, I'le ſweat for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What Sir, preparing for your noble journey?
'Tis well, and full of care.
I ſaw your mind was wedded to the War,
And knew you would prove ſome good man for your Country
Therefore fair Couſin with your gentle pardon,
I got this place: what, mourn at his advancement?
You are to blame, he will come again ſweet Couſin,
Mean time like ſad Penelope and Sage,
Amongſt your Maids at home, and huſwifely.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No Sir, I dare not leave her to that ſolitarineſs.
She is young, and grief or ill news from thoſe quarters
May daily croſs her, ſhe ſhall go along Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: By no means Captain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By all means an't pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What take a young and tender bodied Lady,
And expoſe her to thoſe dangers, and thoſe tumults,
A ſickly Lady too?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Twill make her well Sir,
There's no ſuch friend to health as wholeſom travel.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Away it muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Alon:
sp.l: It ought not Sir,
Go hurry her? it is not humane, Captain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot blame her tears, fright her with tempeſts,
With Thunder of the War.
I dare ſwear if ſhe were able.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She is moſt able.
And pray ye ſwear not, ſhe muſt go, there's no remedy,
Nor greatneſs, nor the trick you had to part us,
Which I ſmell too rank, too open, too evident,
(And I muſt tell you Sir, tis moſt unnoble)
Shall hinder me: had ſhe but ten hours life,
Nay leſs, but two hours, I would have her with me,
I would not leave her ſame to ſo much ruine,
To ſuch a deſolation and diſcredit
As her weakneſs and your hot will wou'd work her too.
What Maſque is this now?
More Troops and Figures, to abuſe my ſufferance,
What Couſin's this?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Michael van owle, how doſt thou?
In what dark Barn or tod of aged Ivy
Haſt thou lain hid?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Things muſt both ebb and flow, Collonel,
And people muſt conceal, and ſhine again.
You are welcom hither as your friend may ſay, Gentlemen,
A pretty houſe ye ſee handſomely ſeated,
Sweet and convenient walks, the Waters cryſtal.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: He's certain mad.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: As mad as a French Taylor,
That has nothing in's head but ends of Fuſtians.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I ſee you are packing now my gentle Couſin,
And my Wife told me I ſhould find it ſo;
'Tis true I do, you were merry when I was laſt here,
But 'twas your will to try my patience, Madam.
I am ſorry that my ſwift occaſions
Can let you take your pleaſure here no longer,
Yet I would have you think my honour'd Couſin,
This houſe and all I have are all your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What houſe, what pleaſure Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You hold the jeſt ſo ſtiff, 'twill prove diſcourteous,
This houſe I mean, the pleaſures of this place.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And what of them?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: They are mine Sir, and you know it,
My wife's I mean, and ſo conferr'd upon me,
The Hangings Sir I muſt entreat, your ſervants,
That are ſo buſie in their offices,
Again to miniſter to their right uſes,
I ſhall take view o'th' Plate anon, and Furnitures
That are of under place; you are merry ſtill Couſin,
And of a pleaſant conſtitution,
Men of great fortunes make their mirths at placitum.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Prithee good ſtubborn Wife, tell me directly,
Good evil Wife leave fooling and tell me honeſtly,
Is this my Kinſman?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I can tell ye nothing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have many Kinſmen, but ſo mad a one,
And ſo phantaſick—all the houſe?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: All mine,
And all within it. I will not bate ye an ace on't.
Can you not receive a noble courteſie,
And quietly and handſomely as ye ought Couz,
But you muſt ride o'th' top on't?

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Canſt thou fight?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'le tell ye preſently, I could have done Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: For we muſt law and claw before we get it.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Away no quarrels.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Now I am more temperate,
I'le have it prov'd if you were never yet in Bedlam,
Never in love, for that's a lunacy,
No great ſtate left ye that you never lookt for,
Nor cannot mannage, that's a rank diſtemper?
That you were chriſten'd, and who anſwer'd for ye,
And then I yield.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: H'as half perſwaded me I was bred i'th' moon,
I have ne'r a buſh at my breech, are not we both mad,
And is not this a phantaſtick houſe we are in,
And all a dream we do? will ye walk out Sir,
And if I do not beat the preſently
Into a ſound belief, as ſenſe can give thee,
Brick me into that wall there for a chimney piece,
And ſay I was one o'th' Caeſars, done by a Seal-cutter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'le talk no more, come we'll away immediately.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why then the Houſe is his, and all that's in it,
I'le give away my Skin but I'le undo ye,
I gave it to his Wife, you muſt reſtore Sir,
And make a new proviſion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Am I mad now, or am I Chriſten'd, you my pagan Couſin.
My mighty mahound Kinſman, what quirk now?
You ſhall be welcom all, I hope to ſee Sir
Your Grace here, and my Couz, we are all Souldiers,
And muſt do naturally for one another.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are ye blank at this? then I muſt tell ye Sir,
Ye have no command, now ye may go at pleaſure
And ride your Aſs Troop, 'twas a trick I us'd
To try you jealouſie upon entreaty,
And ſaving of your Wife.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: All this not moves me,
Nor ſtirs my gall, nor alters my affections,
You have more furniture, more houſes Lady,
And rich ones too, I will make bold with thoſe,
And you have Land i'th' Indies as I take it,
Thither we'll go, and view a while thoſe Climates,
Viſit your Factors there, that may betray ye,
'Tis done, we muſt go.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Now thou art a brave Gentleman,
And by this ſacred light I love thee dearly.
The houſe is none of yours, I did but jeſt Sir,
Nor you are no Couz of mine, I beſeech ye vaniſh,
I tell you plain, you have no more right than he
Has, that ſenſeleſs thing, your wife has once more fool'd ye:
Go ye and conſider.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good morrow my ſweet couſin, I ſhould be glad Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By this hand ſhe dies for't,
Or any man that ſpeaks for her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Theſe are fine Toyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let me requeſt you ſtay but one poor month,
You ſhall have a Commiſſion and I'le go too,
Give me but will ſo far.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well I will try ye,
Good morrow to your Grace, we have private buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If I miſs the again, I am an arrant bungler.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have my command and I'le march under thee,
Nay be thy boy before thou ſhalt be baffled,
Thou art ſo brave a fellow.

sp.speaker: Alonz.
sp.l: I have ſeen Viſions.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Leon, with a Letter, and Margarita.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: COme hither Wife do you know this hand?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I do Sir,
'Tis Eſtifania, that was once my woman.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She writes to me here, that one Cacafogo
An uſuring Jewellers Son (I know the Raſcal)
Is mortally faln in love with ye.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is a monſter, deliver me from Mountains.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you go a birding for all ſorts of people?
And this evening will come to ye and ſhew ye Jewels,
And offers any thing to get acceſs to ye,
If I can make or ſport or profit on him,
(For he is fit for both) ſhe bids me uſe him,
And ſo I will, be you conformable, and follow but my will.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Will the Duke come again do you think?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: No ſure Sir,
H'as now no policy to bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nor bring you to him, if my wit hold fair wife:
Let's in to dinner.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Had I but lungs enough to bawl ſufficiently,
That all the queans in Chriſtendom might hear me,
That men might run away from contagion,
I had my wiſh; would it were moſt high Treaſon,
Moſt infinite high, for any man to marry,
I mean for any man that would live handſomly,
And like a Gentleman, in his wits and credit.
What torments ſhall I put her to, Phalaris bull now?
Pox they love bulling too well, tho they ſmoak for't.
Cut her apieces? every piece will live ſtill,
And every morſel of her will do miſchief;
They have ſo many lives, there's no hanging of 'em;
They are too light to drown, they are cork and feathers;
To burn too cold, they live like Salamanders;
Under huge heeps of Stones to bury her,
And ſo depreſs her as they did the Giants;
She will move under more than built old Babel,
I muſt deſtroy her.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Be cozen'd by a thing of clouts, a ſhe moth,
That every Silkmans ſhop breeds; to be cheated,
And of a thouſand Duckets by a whim wham?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Who's that is cheated, ſpeak again thou viſion,
But art thou cheated? miniſter ſome comfort:
Tell me directly art thou cheated bravely?
Come, prithee come, art thou ſo pure a Coxcomb.
To be undone? do not diſſemble with me,
Tell me I conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Then keep thy circle,
For I am a ſpirit wild that flies about thee,
And who e're thou art, if thou be'ſt humane,
I'le let thee plainly know, I am cheated damnably.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: Doſt thou laugh? damnably, I ſay moſt damnably.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By whom, good ſpirit ſpeak, ſpeak ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cac.
sp.l: I will utter, laugh till thy lungs crack, by a raſcal Woman,
A lewd, abominable, and plain Woman.
Doſt thou laugh ſtill?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I muſt laugh, prithee pardon me;
I ſhall laugh terribly.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I ſhall be angry, terribly angry, I have cauſe.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: That's it, and 'tis no reaſon but thou ſhouldſt be angry,
Angry at heart, yet I muſt laugh ſtill at thee.
By a Woman cheated? art ſure it was a Woman?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I ſhall break thy head, my valour itches at thee.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: It is no matter, by a Woman cozen'd,
A real Woman?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: A real Devil,
Plague of her Jewels and her copper Chains,
How rank they ſmell.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sweet cozen'd Sir let me ſee them,
I have been cheated too, I would have you note that,
And lewdly cheated, by a woman alſo,
A ſcurvy woman, I am undone ſweet Sir,
Therefore I muſt have leave to laugh.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Pray ye take it,
You are the merrieſt undone man in Europe.
What need we Fiddles, bawdy Songs, and Sack,
When our own miſeries can make us merry?

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
I have ſeen theſe Jewels, what a notable penniworth
Have you had next your heart? you will not take Sir
Some twenty Duckets?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Thou art deceiv'd, I will take.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: To clear your bargain now.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: I'le take ſome ten, ſome any thing, ſome half ten,
Half a Ducket.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: An excellent lapidary, ſet theſe ſtones ſure,
Do you mark their Waters?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Quick-ſand choak thei waters,
And hers that brought 'em too, but I ſhall find her.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: And ſo ſhall I, I hope, but do not hurt her,
You cannot find in all this Kingdom,
(If you had need of cozening, as you may have,
For ſuch groſs natures will deſire it often,
'Tis as ſome time too a fine variety,)
A woman that can cozen ye ſo neatly,
She has taken half • ine anger off with this trick.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: If I were valiant now, I would kill this fellow,
I have money enough lies by me at a pinch
I'le to this Lady, there I ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come we'll away unto your Country houſe,
And there we'll learn to live contently,
This place is full of charge, and full of hurry,
No part of ſweetneſs dwells about theſe Cities.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Whither you will, I wait upon your pleaſure;
Live in a hollow Tree Sir, I'le live with ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I, now you ſtrike a harmony, a true one,
When your obedience waits upon your Husband,
And your ſick Will aims at the care of honour,
Why now I dote upon ye, love ye dearly,
And my rough nature falls like roaring ſtreams,
Clearly and ſweetly into your embraces.
O what a Jewel is a woman excellent,
A wiſe, a vertuous and a noble Woman!
When we meet ſuch, we bare our ſtamps on both ſides,
And thro the World we hold our currant virtues,
Alone we are ſingle medals, only faces,
And wear our fortunes out in uſeleſs ſhadows;
Command you now, and eaſe me of that trouble,
I'le be as humble to you as a ſervant,
Bid whom you pleaſe, invite your noble friends,
They ſhall be welcom all, viſit acquaintance,
Go at your pleaſure, now experience
Has link't you faſt unto the chain of goodneſs▪
What noiſe is this, what diſmal cry?

div.stage: Claſhing ſwords. A cry within, down with their ſwords.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: 'Tis loud too.
Sure there's ſome miſchief done i'th' ſtreet, look out there.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Look out and help.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Oh Sir the Duke Medina.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: What of the Duke Medina?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Oh ſweet Gentleman is almoſt ſlain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away, away and help him, all the houſe help.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How ſlain? why Margarita,
Why Wife, ſure ſome new device they have a foot again,
Some trick upon my credit, I ſhall meet it,
I had rather guide a Ship Imperial
Alone, and in a ſtorm, than rule one Woman

div.stage: Enter Duke, Marg. Sanchio, Alonzo, Servant.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: How came ye hurt Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I fell out with my friend the noble Collonel,
My cauſe was nought, for 'twas about your honour:
And he that wrongs the innocent ne'r proſpers,
And he has left me thus for charity,
Lend me a bed to eaſe my tortur'd body,
That e're I periſh I may ſhow my penitence
I fear I am ſlain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Help Gentlemen to carry him,
There ſhall be nothing in this houſe my Lord,
But as your own.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I thank ye noble Sir,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To bed with him, and Wife give your attendance.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Doctors and Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Do not diſquiet me,
But let me take my leave in peace.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Afore me,
'Tis rarely counterfeited.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: True, it is ſo Sir,
And take you heed, this laſt blow do not ſpoil ye,
He is not hurt, only we made a ſcuffle,
As tho we purpos'd anger; that ſame ſcratch
On's hand he took, to colour all and draw compaſſion,
That he might get into your houſe more cunningly.
I muſt not ſtay, ſtand now, and y'are a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank ye noble Collonel, and I honour ye.
Never be quiet?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: He's moſt deſperate ill Sir,
I do not think theſe ten months will recover him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Does he hire my houſe to play the fool in,
Or does it ſtand on Fairy ground, we are haunted,
Are all men and their wives troubled with dreams thus?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What ail you Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What ail you ſweet Wife,
To put theſe daily paſtines on my patience?
What doſt thou ſee in me, that I ſhould ſuffer thus,
Have not I done my part like a true Husband,
And paid ſome deſperate debts you never look'd for?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You have done handſomely I muſt confeſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Have I not kept thee waking like a Hawk?
And watcht thee with delights to ſatisfy thee?
The very tithes of which had won a Widow.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Alas I pity ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me angry,
Thou never ſaw'ſt me mad yet.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You are always,
You carry a kind of Bedlam ſtill about ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If thou purſueſt me further I run ſtark mad
If you have more hurt Dukes or Gentlemen,
To lye here on your cure, I ſhall be deſperate,
I know the trick, and you ſhall feel I know it,
Are ye ſo hot that no hedge can contain ye?
I'le have thee let blood in all the veins about thee,
I'le have thy thoughts found too, and have them open'd,
Thy ſpirits purg'd, for thoſe are they that fire ye,
Thy maid ſhall be thy Miſtreſs, thou the maid,
And all thoſe ſervile labours that ſhe reach at,
And go thro cheerfully, or elſe ſleep empty,
That maid ſhall lye by me to teach you duty,
You in a pallat by to humble ye,
And grieve for what you loſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have loſt my ſelf Sir.
And all that was my baſe ſelf, diſobedience,
My wantonueſs, my ſtubborneſs I have loſt too,
And now by that pure faith good Wives are crown'd with,
By your own nobleneſs.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I take ye up, and wear ye next my heart,
See you be worth it. Now what with you?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: I come to tell my Lady,
There is a fulſome fellow would fain ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis Cacafogo, go and entertain him,
And draw him on with hopes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have a rare deſign upon that Gentleman,
And yon muſt work too.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Away then both, and keep him cloſe in ſome place
From the Dukes ſight, and keep the Duke in too.
Make 'em believe both, I'le find time to cure'em.

div.stage: Enter Perez, and Eſtifania with a Piſtol, and a Dagger.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: Why how darſt thou meet me again thou rebel,
And knowſt how thou haſt uſed me thrice, thou raſcal?
Were there not ways enough to fly my vengeance,
No holes nor vaults to hide thee from my fury,
But thou muſt meet me face to face to kill thee?
I would not ſeek thee to deſtroy thee willingly,
But now thou comeſt to invite me,
And comeſt upon me,
How like a Sheep-biting Rogue taken i'th' manner,
Aud ready for the Halter doſt thou look now?
Thou haſt a hanging look thou ſcurvy thing, haſt ne'r a knife
Nor ever a ſtring to lead thee to Elyſium?
Be there no pitiful 'Pothecaries in this Town,
That have compaſſion upon wretched Women,
And 'dare adminiſter a dram of Rats-bane,
But hou muſt fall to me?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I know you have mercy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If I had tuns of mercy thou deſerv'ſt none,
What new trick is now a foot, and what new Houſes
Have you i'th' air, what Orchards in apparition,
What canſt thou ſay for thy life?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Little or nothing,
I know you'll kill me, and I know 'tis uſeleſs
To beg for mercy, pray let me draw my book out,
And pray a little.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do, a very little,
For I have farther buſineſs than thy killing,
I have money yet to borrow, ſpeak when you are ready.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Now, now Sir, now,
Come on, do you ſtart off from me,
Do you ſwear great Captain, have you ſeen a ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do you wear Guns?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: I am a Souldiers Wife, Sir,
And by that priviledge I may be arm'd,
Now what's the news, and let's diſcourſe more friendly,
And talk of our affairs in peace.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let me ſee,
Prithee let me ſee thy Gun, 'tis a very pretty one.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: No no, Sir, you ſhall feel.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hold ye villain, what thine own Husband?

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Let mine own Husband then
Be in's own wits, there, there's a thouſand Duckets,
Who muſt provide for you, and yet you'll kill me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will not hurt thee for ten thouſand millions.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: When will you redeem your Jewels, I have pawn'd 'em
You ſee for what, we muſt keep touch.

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.l: I'le kiſs thee,
And get as many more, I'le make thee famous,
Had we the houſe now!

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: Come along with me,
If that be vaniſh't there be more to hire Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I ſee I am an Aſs when thou art near me.

div.stage: Enter Leon, Margarita, and Altea, with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Is the fool come?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Yes, and i'th' Cellar faſt,
And there he ſtays his good hour till I call him,
He will make dainty muſick among the Sack-butts,
I have put him juſt, Sir, under the Dukes Chamber.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It is the better.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Has given me royally,
And to my Lady a whole load of Portigues.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Better and better ſtill, go Margarita,
Now play your prize, you ſay you dare be honeſt,
I▪le put ye to your beſt.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Secure your ſelf Sir, give me the Candle,
Paſs away in ſilence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who's there, oh oh.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke within.
sp.l: Have ye brought me comfort?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have my Lord,
Come forth, tis I, come gently out I'le help ye.
Come ſoftly too, how do you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are there none here?
Let me look round; we cannot be too wary,
Oh let me bleſs this hour, are you alone ſweet friend?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Alone to comfort you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's that you tumble?
I have heard a noiſe this half hour under me,
A fearful noiſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: The ſat thing's mad i'th' Cellar,
And ftumbles from one Hogs-head to another,
Two cups more, and he ne'r ſhall find the way out.
What do you fear? come, ſit down by me chearfully,
My Husband's ſafe, how do your wounds?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I have none Lady,
My wounds I counterfeited cunningly,
And feign'd the quarrel too, to injoy you ſweet,
Let's loſe no time, hark the ſame noiſe again.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What noiſe, why look ye pale? I hear no ſtirring,
This goblin in the Vault will be ſo tippled.
You are not well I know by your flying fancy,
Your body's ill at eaſe, your wounds.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I have none, I am as luſty and as full of health,
High in my blood.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Weak in your blood you would ſay,
How wretched is my caſe, willing to pleaſe ye,
And find you ſo diſable?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Believe me Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I know you will venture all you have to ſatisfy me,
Your life I know, but is it fit I ſpoil ye,
Is it my love do you think?

sp.speaker: Caca. below.
sp.l: Here's to the Duke

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It nam'd me certainly,
heard it plainly ſound.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You are hurt mortally,
And ſitter for your prayers Sir, than pleaſure,
What ſtarts you make? I would not kiſs you wantonly,
For the Worlds wealth; have I ſecur'd my Husband,
And put all doubts aſide to be deluded?

sp.speaker: Caca. below.
sp.l: I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And bleſs us both, for ſure this is the Devil,
I plainly heard it now, he will come to fetch ye,
A very ſpirit, for the ſpoke under ground,
And ſpoke to you juſt as you would have ſnatcht me,
You are a wicked man, and ſure this haunts ye,
Would you were out o'th houſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would I were,
O'that condition I had leapt a window.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: And that's the leaſt leap if you mean to ſcape Sir,
Why what a frantick man were you to come here,
What a weak man to counterfeit deep wounds,
To wound another deeper?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Are you honeſt then?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Yes then and now, and ever, and excellent honeſt,
And exerciſe this paſtime but to ſhew ye,
Great men are fools ſometimes as well as wretches.
Would you were well hurt, with any hope of life,
Cut to the Brains, or run clean thro the body,
To get out quietly as you got in Sir,
I wiſh it like a friend that loves you dearly,
For if my Husband take ye, and take ye thus a counterfeit;
One that would clip his credit out of his honour,
He muſt kill ye preſently,
There is no mercy nor an hour of pity,
And for me to entreat in ſuch an agony,
Would ſhew me little better than one guilty,
Have you any mind to a Lady now?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would I were off fair,
If ever Lady caught me in a trap more.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: If you be well and luſty, fie, fie, ſhake not,
You ſay you love me, come, come bravely now,
Deſpiſe all danger, I am ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: She mocks my miſery, thou cruel Lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Thou cruel Lord, wouldſt thou betray my honeſty,
Betray it in mine own houſe, wrong my Husband,
Like a night Thief, thou darſt not name by day-night?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am moſt miſerable.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You are indeed,
And like a fooliſh thing you have made your ſelf ſo,
Could not your own diſcretion tell ye Sir,
When I was married I was none of yours?
Your Eyes were then commanded to look off me,
And I now ſtand in a circle and ſecure,
Your ſpells nor power can never reach my body,
Mark me but this, and then Sir be moſt miſerable,
'Tis ſacriledge to violate a Wedlock,
You rob two Temples, make your ſelf twice guilty,
You ruine hers, and ſpot her noble Husbands.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let me be gone, I'le never more attempt ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You cannot go, 'tis not in me to ſave ye,
Dare ye do ill, and poorly then ſhrink under it?
Were I the Duke Medina, I would fight now,
For you muſt fight and bravely, it concerns you,
You do me double wrong if you ſneak off Sir,
And all the world would ſay I lov'd a coward,
And you muſt dye too, for you will be kill'd,
And leave your youth, your honour and your ſtate,
And all thoſe dear delights you worſhip'd here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The noiſe again!

sp.speaker: Cacaf. below.
sp.l: Some ſmall Beer if you love me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Devil haunts you ſure, your ſins are mighty,
A drunken Devil too, to plague your villany.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Preſerve me but this once.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: There's a deep Well
In the next yard, if you dare venture drowning,
It is but death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I would not dye ſo wretchedly.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Out of a Garret window I'le let you down then,
But ſay the rope be rotten, 'tis huge high too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Have you no mercy?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Now you are frighted throughly,
And find what 'tis to play the fool in folly.
And ſee with clear eyes your deteſted folly,
I'le be your guard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And I'le be your true ſervant,
Ever from this hour vertuouſly to love ye,
Chaſtly and modeſtly to look upon ye,
And here I ſeal it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I may kiſs a ſtranger, for you muſt now be ſo,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: How do you my Lord,
Methinks you look but poorly on this matter.
Has my Wife wounded ye, you were well before,
Pray Sir be comforted, I have forgot all,
Truly forgiven too, Wife you are a right one,
And now with unknown Nations I dare truſt ye.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: No more feign'd fights my Lord, they never proſper.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who's this? the Devil in the vault?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: 'Tis he Sir, and as lovingly drunk, as tho he had ſtudied it.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Give me a cup of Sack, and kiſs me Lady,
Kiſs my ſweet face, and make thy Husband Cuckold,
An Ocean of ſweet Sack, ſhall we ſpeak Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: He is Deviliſh drunk.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I had thought he had been a Devil,
He made as many noiſes and as horrible.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Oh a true lover Sir will lament loudly,
Which of the Butts is your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Butt in thy belly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There's two in thine I am ſure, 'tis grown ſo monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Caca.
sp.l: Butt in thy face.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Go carry him to ſleep,
A fools love ſhould be drunk, he has paid well for't too.
When he is ſober let him out to rail,
Or hang himſelf, there will be no loſs of him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who's this? my Mauhound Couſin?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: GOod Sir, 'tis very good, would I had a houſe too,
For there is no talking in the open Air,
My Tarmagant Cuz, I would be bold to tell ye,
I durſt be merry too; I tell you plainly,
You have a pretty ſeat, you have the luck on't,
A pretty Lady too, I have miſt both,
My Carpenter built in a miſt I thank him,
Do me the courteſy to let me ſee it,
See it but once more. But I ſhall cry for anger.
I'le hire a Chandlers Shop cloſe under ye,
And for my foolery, ſell Sope and Whip-cord,
Nay if you do not laugh now and laugh heartily,
You are a fool Cuz.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I muſt laugh a little,
And now I have done, Cuz thou ſhalt live with me,
My merry Cuz, the World ſhall not divorce us,
Thou art a valiant man, and thou ſhalt never want,
Will this content thee?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'le cry, and then I'le be thankful,
Indeed I will, and I'le be honeſt to ye.
I would live a ſwallow here I muſt confeſs.
Wife I forgive thee all if thou be honeſt,
At thy peril, I believe thee excellent.

sp.speaker: Eſtif.
sp.l: If I prove otherways, let me beg firſt,
Hold, this is yours, ſome recompence for ſervice,
Uſe it to nobler ends than he that gave it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And this is yours, your true commiſſion Sir,
Now you are a Captain.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You are a noble Prince Sir,
And now a Souldier, Gentleman, we all rejoyce in't.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Sir, I ſhall wait upon you thro all fortunes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: And I muſt needs attend my miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Will you go Siſter?

sp.speaker: Altea.
sp.l: Yes indeed good Brother,
I have two ties, mine own blood,
And my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Is ſhe your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes indeed good Wife,
And my beſt Siſter,
For ſhe prov'd ſo, wench,
When ſhe deceiv'd you with a loving Husband.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I would not deal ſo truly for a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well I could chide ye,
But it muſt be lovingly and like a Siſter,
I'le bring you on your way, and feaſt ye nobly,
For now I have an honeſt heart to love ye,
And then deliver you to the blue Neptune.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Your colours you muſt wear, and wear 'em proudly,
Wear 'em before the bullet, and in blood too,
And all the World ſhall know
We are Vertues ſervants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And all the world ſhall know, a noble mind
Makes Women beautiful, and envy blind.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: Good night our worthy friends, and may you part
Each with as merry and as free a heart,
As you came hither; to thoſe noble eyes,
That deign to ſmile on our poor faculties,
And give a bleſſing to our labouring ends,
As we hope many, to ſuch fortune ſends
Their own deſires, Wives fair as light as chaſte;
To thoſe that live by ſpight Wives made in haſte.
